hints_html:
Make sure you remember which direction the discs are going.

The volume is given by \(\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx\)

Remember to revolve around \(\displaystyle y = -1\), not \(\displaystyle y = 0\). How does this affect the radius?
hints_latex: Make sure you remember which direction the discs are going.

The volume is given by
$\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx$

Remember to revolve around $\displaystyle y = -1$, not
$\displaystyle y = 0$. How does this affect the radius?
hints_raw:
Make sure you remember which direction the discs are going.
The volume is given by <math>\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx</math>
Remember to revolve around <math>\displaystyle y = -1</math>, not <math>\displaystyle y = 0</math>. How does this affect the radius?
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
To begin with, to get our bounds of integration and where the intersection points are, we follow same steps as in part (a) to find that the curves intersect when \(\displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2\). Further, the top function on \(\displaystyle [\pi/2,\pi]\) is \(\displaystyle 4+\pi \sin x\), whereas the top function on \(\displaystyle [\pi,3\pi/2]\) is \(\displaystyle 4+2\pi-2x\).

Since we are revolving around the horizontal line \(\displaystyle y = -1\), the radius of the discs change for every value of x. Hence we will integrate over all x values to get the volume of revolution. To find the radius of the discs as a function of x, note that we need to add 1 to the function value since the radius is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \text{radius = } \text{function} - \text{axis} = f(x)-(-1) = f(x)+1\end{aligned}\]

where \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is the function. The volume of revolution is given by \(\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx\), so

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \pi\int_{\pi/2}^\pi [(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2-(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2] \ dx \\ & \qquad + \pi\int_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} [(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2-(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2] \ dx\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
To begin with, to get our bounds of integration and where the
intersection points are, we follow same steps as in
{part
(a)} to find that the curves intersect when
$\displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2$. Further, the top function on
$\displaystyle [\pi/2,\pi]$ is $\displaystyle 4+\pi \sin x$, whereas the
top function on $\displaystyle [\pi,3\pi/2]$ is
$\displaystyle 4+2\pi-2x$.

Since we are revolving around the horizontal line
$\displaystyle y = -1$, the radius of the discs change for every value
of \emph{x}. Hence we will integrate over all \emph{x} values to get the
volume of revolution. To find the radius of the discs as a function of
\emph{x}, note that we need to add 1 to the function value since the
radius is given by

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \text{radius = } \text{function} - \text{axis} = f(x)-(-1) = f(x)+1
\end{align*}

where $\displaystyle f(x)$ is the function. The volume of revolution is
given by
$\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx$,
so

\begin{align*}
V &= \pi\int_{\pi/2}^\pi [(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2-(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2] \ dx \\
& \qquad + \pi\int_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} [(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2-(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2] \ dx
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
To begin with, to get our bounds of integration and where the intersection points are, we follow same steps as in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2013/Question_04_(a)|part (a)]] to find that the curves intersect when <math> \displaystyle x = \pi/2, \pi, 3\pi/2</math>. Further, the top function on <math> \displaystyle [\pi/2,\pi]</math> is <math> \displaystyle 4+\pi \sin x </math>, whereas the top function on <math> \displaystyle [\pi,3\pi/2]</math> is <math> \displaystyle 4+2\pi-2x </math>.

Since we are revolving around the horizontal line <math> \displaystyle y = -1 </math>, the radius of the discs change for every value of ''x''. Hence we will integrate over all ''x'' values to get the volume of revolution. To find the radius of the discs as a function of ''x'', note that we need to add 1 to the function value since the radius is given by

:<math> \displaystyle \text{radius = } \text{function} - \text{axis} = f(x)-(-1) = f(x)+1 </math>

where <math> \displaystyle f(x) </math> is the function. The volume of revolution is given by <math>\displaystyle \pi \int_a^b (\text{outer radius}^2-\text{inner radius}^2) \ dx</math>, so

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
\begin{align}
V & = \pi\int_{\pi/2}^\pi [(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2-(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2] \ dx \\
& \qquad + \pi\int_{\pi}^{3\pi/2} [(4+2\pi-2x+1)^2-(4+\pi\sin x+1)^2] \ dx
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 4â€“12, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

The graph below shows the region between \(\displaystyle y = 4+\pi \sin x\) and \(\displaystyle y = 4+2\pi-2x\)

The region is rotated about the line \(y = -1\). Express in terms of definite integrals the volume of the resulting solid. Do not evaluate the integrals. Also, it is not necessary to simplify them.
statement_raw:
'''Full-Solution Problems'''. In questions 4–12, justify your answers and '''show all your work'''. If
a box is provided, write your final answer there. '''Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions'''.

'''The graph below shows the region between <math> \displaystyle y = 4+\pi \sin x</math> and <math> \displaystyle y = 4+2\pi-2x</math>'''

[[File:MATH101April2013Q4.jpg]]

The region is rotated about the line <math> y = -1 </math>. Express in terms of definite integrals the volume of the resulting solid. ''Do not'' evaluate the integrals. Also, it is not necessary to simplify them.
